Indicator 08. 0% of people surveyed who report that their level of trust toward others have increased as a result of their participation in training initiatives Indicator 09 . 0% Households purchasing technologies reporting and improved perception of women and youth as a result of market transactions facilitated by the programme (diaggregated by men and women) Indicator 10. No Early Recovery strategies developed and implemented (national, Rakhine and Kachin); Indicator 11. 0 Early Recovery principles integrated in humanitarian sector/ cluster response plans;

Indiactor 1. 40:100 women representatives in community-led governance structures in target locations (All Areas) Indicator 2. 70% of persons targeted for livelihood assistance reporting increased income-levels in target locations 06 months after having received support Indicator 3. 80% of persons targeted for micro-enterprise support reporting sustaining their enterprises 6 months after having received support Indicator 4. 300,000 persons using/accessing constructed/ rehabilitated infrastructure Indicator 5. 46.5 households (50% increase) reporting ‘more than 5’ occasions for interacting with a member from another village/ethnicity in past 06 months Indicator 6. 50% of households reporting perceptions of increased unity between people from other villages/communities in the past 6 months as a result of UNDP's interventions (disaggregated by gender) (All Areas) Indicator 7. NA Indicator 8. NA Indicator 9. NA Indicator 10. Recovery Network Strategy developed for target locations (Rakhine and Kachin). Indicator 11. Integration of ER principles in at least 2 humanitarian sector/ cluster response plans

Support reached up to 196,571 people in 113 villages in Mon, Kachin, Kayin, Rakhine and Shan states. Key interventions included support to rural and flood and conflict-affected communities in Rakhine; support to returnees and host-communities in Kachin, and the roll-out of a pilot initiative to improve market-based livelihood opportunities for rural communities by increasing their access to innovative technologies in Mon, Kayin and Shan. In 2015, Capital assistance reached 113 persons (48% women); 23,107 (52% women) persons benefitted from access to new infrastructure; and 40 young entrepreneurs (65% women) have established businesses selling fuel-efficient and renewable energy products in their communities. By end-2015, up to 89% of those receiving capital assistance for agriculture, livestock and fisheries reported an increase in income and 100% of those receiving capital assistance for enterprises reported sustaining their enterprise, both 6 months following the receipt of support. The Programme also reported 47 female CBO members for every 100, an increase from a baseline of 25 persons, and 82% households reporting an increase in opportunities for interaction between different communities, an increase from a baseline of 46.5 households. While ongoing in 2016, 589 persons from a cross-section of local government, CSOs and none-state actors (ethnic armed organizations) have developed their capacities to train local stakeholders in six states.
